coredata.dc:title: Discovery of fluorescent coumarin-benzo[b]thiophene 1, 1-dioxide conjugates as mitochondria-targeting antitumor STAT3 inhibitors
coredata.prism:publicationName: European Journal of Medicinal ChemistryJournalfla02235234174236251236-251text/xml2019-07-1515 July 2019© 2019 Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.Elsevier Masson SAS.Cai, GuipingYu, WenyingSong, DongmeiZhang, WendaGuo, JianpengZhu, JiawenRen, YuhaoKong, Lingyi STAT3 has been extensively studied as a potential antitumor target. Though studies on regulating STAT3 mainly focus on the inhibition of STAT3 phosphorylation at Tyr705 residue, the phosphorylation at Ser727 residue of STAT3 protein is also closely associated with the mitochondrial import of STAT3 protein. N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin is a fluorescent mitochondria-targeting probe. In this study, a series of STAT3 inhibitors were developed by connecting N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin fluorophore with benzo [b]thiophene 1, 1-dioxide moiety. All designed compounds displayed potent anti-proliferative activity against cancer cells. The representative compound 7a was mainly accumulated in mitochondria visualized by its fluorescence. STAT3 phosphorylation was inhibited by compound 7a at both Tyr705 and Ser727 residues. Compound 7a inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation whereas had no influence on the phosphorylation levels of STAT1, JAK2, Src and Erk1/2, indicating good selectivity of compound 7a. Moreover, compound 7a down-regulated the expression of STAT3 target genes Bcl-2 and Cyclin D1, increased ROS production and remarkably reduced the mitochondrial membrane potential to induce mitochondrial apoptotic pathway. Furthermore, compound 7a in vivo suppressed breast cancer 4T1 implanted tumor growth. Taken together, these results highlighted that compound 7a might be a promising mitochondria-targeting STAT3 inhibitor for cancer therapy. 0falsefalseSTAT3Benzo[b]thiophene 1, 1-Dioxide N, N-Diethyl-7-aminocoumarin fluorophoreSer727 phosphorylationMitochondrial apoptosis pathwayAntitumor activity

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Design strategy of the coumarin-benzo [b]thiophene 1, 1-dioxide conjugates for targeting mitochondria and tumor therapy.

Compound 7a inhibited MDA-MB-231 cells proliferation in vitro. MDA-MB-231 cells were treated with compound 7a at tested concentrations for 24 h. Cells were subcultured to fresh medium and allowed to grow until the colonies were visible.

Apoptotic effects of compound 7a on MDA-MB-231 cells. MDA-MB-231 cells were treated with compound 7a at tested concentrations for 24 h. (A) Apoptotic effects were detected using Annexin V-FITC/PI staining by flow cytometry. (B) The histograms for % of apoptosis (early and late stages of apoptosis). ***, p < 0.001, **, p < 0.01. (C) The effects of compound 7a on protein levels of Caspase-9, Cleaved Caspase-9, Caspase-3, Cleaved Caspase-3, PARP and Cleaved PARP. Cell lysates were harvested and analyzed using the corresponding antibodies by western blotting. (D) Quantitative analysis of western blotting by Image Lab program with GAPDH as the internal control. ***, p < 0.001. **, p < 0.01.

Subcellular localization studies of compound 7a in MDA-MB-231 cells and MCF-7 cells. Images of cells pretreated, respectively, with compound 7a for 60 min, and subsequently, 1 μM MitoTracker Red (Fig. 4b) or 1 μM LysoTracker Red (Fig. S2b in the Supporting Information) for 30 min. (a) Probe fluorescence, blue channel; (b) MitoTracker, red channel; (c) The overlap.

Compound 7a affected mitochondrial membrane potential in MDA-MB-231 cells. (A) MDA-MB-231 cells were treated with compound 7a at tested concentrations for 24 h analyzed using flow cytometer after JC-1 staining. (B) The ratios of red fluorescence to green fluorescence. **, p < 0.01, ***, p < 0.001.

Compound 7a induced ROS generation. MDA-MB-231 cells were treated with compound 7a at tested concentrations for 24 h. (A) The ROS accumulation in MDA-MB-231 cells measured by flow cytometer using DCFH-DA staining. (B) Relative ROS levels of MDA-MB-231 cells after treatment with compound 7a for 24 h *, p < 0.05, **, p < 0.01.

Compound 7a inhibited STAT3 activation and the effects of compound 7a on protein levels of STAT3 related proteins. MDA-MB-231 cells were treated with compound 7a at tested concentrations for 24 h and then the cell lysates were harvested and analyzed using the corresponding antibodies by western blotting or EMSA analysis. (A) The effects of compound 7a on STAT3, p-STAT3 (Y705), p-STAT3 (S727), STAT1 and p-STAT1 (Y701) protein levels in MDA-MB-231 cells by western blotting analysis using GAPDH as a control. (B) EMSA analysis of nuclear extracts of equal total protein containing activated STAT3 from MDA-MB-231 cells treated with compound 7a or Stattic for 24 h after incubation with hSIE probe that binds STAT3. (C) The effects of compound 7a on protein levels of upstream tyrosine kinases p-JAK2, Src, p-Src and bypass tyrosine kinase Erk1/2 and p-Erk1/2. (D) The effects of compound 7a on expression levels of STAT3 related downstream gene Bcl-2 and Cyclin D1 and the quantitative analysis of western blotting by Image Lab program with GAPDH as the internal control. **, p < 0.01, ***, p < 0.001.

Molecular docking model of compound 7a binding to SH2 domain of STAT3 generated by Autodock 4.2. (A) Carbon atoms of compound 7a were colored magenta. STAT3 protein was represented as white ribbon and the key residues were shown. Hydrogen bonds were represented by green lines. (B) Compound 7a bound to hot spot pTyr705 site and side pocket of STAT3 SH2 domain (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.).

Compound 7a inhibited the growth of mouse sarcoma xenograft tumors in vivo. (A) The weight of tumor tissues of control and treated mice. (B) The tumor growth inhibitory rates of compound 7a (10 mg/kg, 20 mg/kg). (C) The growing curves of mice's tumor volume. (D) Anatomical mice's tumor tissue untreated or treated with compound 7a (10 mg/kg, 20 mg/kg). (E) Western blotting analysis of p-STAT3 (Y705) and STAT3 levels in tumor tissues prepared from control or mice treated with compound 7a (10 mg/kg, 20 mg/kg). **, p < 0.01, ***, p < 0.001.

Synthesis of fluorescent coumarin-benzo [b]thiophene 1, 1-dioxide conjugates compound 7a-7o. Reagents and conditions: (a) HSCH2COOCH3, DMF, 60 °C, 15 h; (b) 10% KOH, reflux, 3 h, 1 M HCl; (c) tert-butyl-1-piperazine-carboxylate, HATU, DIEA, DCM, rt., 12 h; (d) m-CPBA, DCM, 45 °C, 5 h; (e) (i) TFA, DCM, rt., 2 h; (ii) HATU, DIEA, DCM, rt., 12 h.
Anti-proliferative activity of the designed compounds 7a-7o, compound 8 and the reference compound Stattic.

ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: The inhibitory effects of individual compounds on the proliferation of the four cell lines were determined by the MTT assay. SD: standard deviation, all experiments were independently performed at least three times.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Anti-proliferative activity and selectivity index of compound 7a and Stattic on MCF-10 A and L02 cells.

head.ce:title: Discovery of fluorescent coumarin-benzo[b]thiophene 1, 1-dioxide conjugates as mitochondria-targeting antitumor STAT3 inhibitors

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Bioactive Natural Product Research and State Key Laboratory of Natural Medicines, China Pharmaceutical University, 24 Tong Jia Xiang, Nanjing, 210009, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Bioactive Natural Product Research and State Key Laboratory of Natural Medicines

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: Both authors contributed equally to this paper.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: STAT3 has been extensively studied as a potential antitumor target. Though studies on regulating STAT3 mainly focus on the inhibition of STAT3 phosphorylation at Tyr705 residue, the phosphorylation at Ser727 residue of STAT3 protein is also closely associated with the mitochondrial import of STAT3 protein. N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin is a fluorescent mitochondria-targeting probe. In this study, a series of STAT3 inhibitors were developed by connecting N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin fluorophore with benzo [b]thiophene 1, 1-dioxide moiety. All designed compounds displayed potent anti-proliferative activity against cancer cells. The representative compound 7a was mainly accumulated in mitochondria visualized by its fluorescence. STAT3 phosphorylation was inhibited by compound 7a at both Tyr705 and Ser727 residues. Compound 7a inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation whereas had no influence on the phosphorylation levels of STAT1, JAK2, Src and Erk1/2, indicating good selectivity of compound 7a. Moreover, compound 7a down-regulated the expression of STAT3 target genes Bcl-2 and Cyclin D1, increased ROS production and remarkably reduced the mitochondrial membrane potential to induce mitochondrial apoptotic pathway. Furthermore, compound 7a in vivo suppressed breast cancer 4T1 implanted tumor growth. Taken together, these results highlighted that compound 7a might be a promising mitochondria-targeting STAT3 inhibitor for cancer therapy.

Compound 7a acted as a mitochondria-targeting STAT3 inhibitor to exert antitumor activities in vitro and in vivo.
Image 1

ce:keyword.ce:text: signal transducer and activator of transcription

ce:section.ce:para: Signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3), a latent cytoplasmic transcription factor, has been documented to play vital roles in a series of biological processes, such as cell proliferation, differentiation, development, survival, apoptosis and immunization [1–5]. Persistent activation of STAT3 by cytokines or growth factors exists in many solid and hematopoietic malignancies [5–8], making it a promising target for cancer therapy.

As the powerhouse of cells and important intracellular organelles, mitochondria exert both crucial and lethal functions in physiological and pathological processes that generate metabolic energy via oxidative phosphorylation, maintain calcium homeostasis, produce cellular signaling by reactive oxygen species (ROS) and regulate the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis [9–14]. High level of ROS irreversibly results in DNA damage and ultimately causes apoptosis and necrosis of cancer cell [15]. And changes in mitochondrial membrane potential (Δψ m) play an important role in mitochondrial apoptosis [16]. Emerging evidence indicates that a portion of STAT3 is located in the mitochondria and exerts an influence on the levels of ROS and Δψ m to modulate mitochondrial apoptotic pathways [17–24].

STAT3 activation is regulated by phosphorylation on tyrosine 705 (Tyr705) through receptor tyrosine kinases, which leads to its homodimerization, translocation into nucleus, DNA-binding and downstream transcriptional activities [17]. Whereas, except for Tyr705 phosphorylation, phosphorylation at serine 727 (Ser727) residue is also associated with the transcription, mitochondrial import and other biological functions of STAT3 protein [20,21,25–27]. In consequence, we speculated that simultaneous suppression of phosphorylation at Tyr705 and Ser727 residues might suppress STAT3 activation to a greater extent and thereby treat cancer.

The benzo [b]thiophene 1, 1-dioxide (BTP) moiety has the potential to inhibit Tyr705 phosphorylation of STAT3 as well as prominently suppress proliferation and enhance apoptosis of tumor cell by means of promoting ROS production. This makes BTP moiety an important pharmacophore of multiple STAT3 inhibitors, such as Stattic, HJC0123 and HJC0146 [28–34].

Fluorescent probes targeting on subcellular organelles could function as real-time monitors of the therapeutic outcomes [35–37]. Coumarins were selected as fluorescent probes owing to their good physical properties, such as good water-solubility, photostability, small size and nontoxicity [38,39]. Fluorescent N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin with delocalized lipophilic cation can permeate the living cell membranes and accumulate preferentially in the mitochondria of cancer cells to be fluorescent mitochondria-targeted theranostic probe [40–42]. In 2015, Xu Zhang et al. reported that conjugating N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin fluorophore with antimalarial drug artemisinin could enhance anticancer activity, owing to the mitochondrial accumulation of artemisinin by the probe [42]. Similarly, Hong Yao et al. reported the possible anticancer mechanism of 23-hydroxybetulinic acid derivatives by combining fluorescent N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin with 23-hydroxybetulinic acid derivatives in 2018 [43].

Schemes 1 outlined the synthetic routes for compounds 7a-7o. The methyl benzo [b]thiophene-2-carboxylates 2a-2n were prepared from the commercially available starting materials 1a-1n and methyl thioglycolate, and were conveniently hydrolyzed to provide the corresponding acids 3a-3n as described previously [31,34]. Using 2-(7-Azabenzotriazol-1-yl)-N,N,Nʹ,Nʹ-tetra-methyluronium hexafluorophosphate (HATU) as a coupling reagent, compounds 3a-3o were reacted with tert-butyl-1-piperazinecarboxylate to afford intermediates 4a-4o, which were then oxidized by 3-chloroperoxybenzoic acid to produce 2-carbonylbenzo [b]thiophene 1, 1-dioxides 5a-5o [31,34]. After deprotecting N-Boc protection of 5a-5o with trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), the desired compounds 7a-7o were prepared by coupling with 7-(Diethylamino)coumarin-3-carboxylic acid 6 in the presence of HATU. All hybrids were confirmed by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, IR, and HRMS (ESI) spectrum.

ce:section.ce:section-title: In vitro cell growth inhibition activity
ce:section.ce:para: To evaluate in vitro tumor cell growth inhibitory activity of all compounds and explore the structure-activity relationships, four STAT3 over-activated human cancer cell lines, including human breast carcinoma MDA-MB-231 cells and MCF-7 cells, human colonic carcinoma HCT-116 cells and human hepatocellular carcinoma HepG2 cells, were treated with designed compounds and the positive control Stattic, by MTT assay. As shown in Table 1 , all designed compounds displayed potent anti-proliferative activity against four cancer cells. In contrast to BTP (IC50 = 27.65 μM for MDA-MB-231 cells), the intercalation of fluorescent coumarin (7o) significantly enhanced cell growth inhibitory activity. In general, compounds with electron-withdrawing substitutes such as nitro substituent (7j and 7l) or halogen substituents (7c, 7e, 7g, 7h and 7i) were less active than those with electron-donating substitutes such as methoxy substituent (7m and 7n) except compound 7a, which bears a bromo substituent at 4 position of the BTP ring. Compared with compound 7o, compounds with the methoxy substituent (such as 7m and 7n) exhibited enhanced anticancer activity, while that with nitro substituent (7j, 7k and 7l) led to a decreased activity. The compound with a 4-bromo substitute on the BTP ring (7a) had a slightly stronger activity than compounds with a bromine substitute at 5, 6 or 7 position on the BTP ring (7b, 7c and 7d). The most potent compound 7a inhibited the growth of MDA-MB-231, HCT-116, HepG2, and MCF-7 cells with IC50 values of 1.43, 1.89, 2.88, and 3.33 μM respectively, which showed 4.6- to 19-fold improvement in activity than compound 8 (BTP). The anti-proliferative effects of compound 7a on normal cells were investigated by MTT assays subsequently. As shown in Table 2 , Stattic has growth inhibition activity in both tumor and normal cells, while compound 7a exhibited selective inhibitory activity against cancer cells (IC50 = 14.62 μM for MCF-10 A cells and IC50 = 35.60 μM for L02 cells) and selectivity index was 10.2 and 12.4 respectively, indicating in vitro comparatively better safety of compound 7a than Stattic.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 7a reduced colony formation in vitro
ce:section.ce:para: STAT3 has been demonstrated to drive colony formation, which was mediated by its phosphorylation of Tyr705 and Ser727 [20]. Consequently, we performed colony survival assay to further explore the anti-proliferative activity of compound 7a. As shown in Fig. 2 , treatment with 1 μM of compound 7a markedly inhibited the proliferation of MDA-MB-231 cells and there was almost a cessation of colony formation at 2 μM compound 7a. Therefore, similar to data from the MTT assays, compound 7a could suppress the proliferation of STAT3 dependent MDA-MB-231 cells.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 7a induced apoptosis in cancer cells
ce:section.ce:para: To explore whether the anti-proliferative potency of compound 7a was consistent with the induction of apoptosis, Annexin V-FITC/PI staining assay was performed by flow cytometry. The results showed that compound 7a could induce the apoptosis of MDA-MB-231 cells dose-dependently and the apoptosis rates (early and late apoptosis) at 0, 1, 2, 4 μM were 4.2%, 6.6%, 9.2% and 20.4% (Fig. 3 A). To confirm that apoptotic effects in MDA-MB-231 cells by compound 7a were exerted via the mitochondrial pathway, we evaluated the protein levels of Cleaved Caspases-9 and Cleaved Caspases-3 and Cleaved PARP in MDA-MB-231 cells after treatment with compound 7a (1–4 μM) or Stattic (4 μM) for 24 h by western blotting. As shown in Fig. 3B, compound 7a could induce the cleavage of Caspase-9, Caspase-3 and PARP, which were similar to the positive STAT3 inhibitor Stattic (Fig. S1A in the Supporting Information). Thus, we supposed that cytotoxicity of compound 7a in cancer cells is mainly through the mitochondrial Caspase-dependent apoptotic pathway, which was potentially regulated by the deactivation of STAT3 protein.

It was reported that compounds conjugated with the N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin fluorophore might accumulate in mitochondria [41,42]. To determine the role of compound 7a as a mitochondrial probe, we investigated the subcellular localization of compound 7a. MitoTracker (mitochondria-specific dye; Fig. 4 b), and LysoTracker (Lysosome-specific dye; Fig. S2b in the Supporting Information) were employed for colocalization experiments in human breast carcinoma MDA-MB-231 cells and MCF-7 cells. The preferential concentration of compound 7a for study was 2 μM and 5 μM respectively. MDA-MB-231 cells and MCF-7 cells were stained by compound 7a after 60 min of incubation and strong blue fluorescence was detected as shown in Fig. 4a and Fig. S2a (Supporting Information). The colocalization study revealed that the fluorescence of compound 7a overlapped exactly with that of MitoTracker Red, with an extensive magenta color in the merged image (Fig. 4c) but that of Lysosome, with only partial colocalization (Fig. S2c in the Supporting Information). The results confirmed that compound 7a was accumulated to mitochondria by the aid of the fluorescent N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin moiety.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 7a affected the mitochondrial membrane potential (Δψm)
ce:section.ce:para:
The level of mitochondrial membrane potential (Δψ
m
) was more elevated in cancer cells than that in normal cells, which could be exploited therapeutically to selectively target compounds to the mitochondria of cancer cells [52]. And changes in Δψ
m have been shown to play an important role in mitochondrial apoptosis [16]. Taking into consideration that the hybrids were designed to target mitochondria and to induce mitochondrial apoptosis, we continued to investigate the effect of compound 7a on Δψ m of MDA-MB-231 cells using JC-1 assay kit. Changes in Δψ m were reflected by the increase of J-monomers (green fluorescence) and concurrent decrease of J-aggregates (red fluorescence). As shown in Fig. 5 , treatment with compound 7a led to increased intensity of green fluorescence in a dose-dependent manner. These data suggested that compound 7a induced the depolarization of mitochondrial membrane potential and subsequently induced mitochondrial damage and apoptosis of cancer cells.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 7a induced the ROS generation in cancer cells
ce:section.ce:para: Mitochondria are the main organelle that produce ROS and previous studies have suggested that constitutively activated STAT3 phosphorylated on Ser727 in the mitochondria could decrease the amount of ROS, causing decreased apoptosis and enhanced tumor cell growth [5,21,53]. We next evaluated ROS production after treating with compound 7a at different concentrations in MDA-MB-231 cells for 24 h by flow cytometry analysis. As shown in Fig. 6 , compound 7a induced ROS accumulation in a dose-dependent manner, indicating that compound 7a could increase ROS production which is also responsible for mitochondrial apoptosis and necrosis of cancer cell.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 7a inhibited STAT3 tyrosine phosphorylation and serine phosphorylation
ce:section.ce:para: BTP moiety could suppress the phosphorylation of STAT3 on Tyr705 but have minimal impact on STAT3 phosphorylation on Ser727 [33]. To examine whether the aforementioned improved antitumor activities in vitro were derived from addition of the mitochondria-targeting N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin fluorophore to inhibit STAT3 phosphorylation at Ser727 residue, the p-STAT3 (Tyr705 and Ser727) protein levels were investigated on MDA-MB-231 cells by western blotting assays. MDA-MB-231 cells were treated with compound 7a (1–4 μM) or Stattic (4 μM) for 24 h and the phosphorylated and total STAT3 protein levels were examined. As shown in Fig. 7 A, compound 7a markedly inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation at Tyr705 residue as well as STAT3 phosphorylation at Ser727 residue in a dose-dependent manner but total STAT3 proteins remain unaffected, while Stattic only inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation at Tyr705 residue (Fig. S1B in the Supporting Information). These results indicated that compound 7a was a dual STAT3 inhibitor that including BTP moiety to suppress the phosphorylation of STAT3 on Tyr705 and the mitochondria-targeting N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin fluorophore to make compound accumulate to mitochondria, inhibit STAT3 phosphorylation on Ser727 and thereby induce mitochondrial damage and apoptosis.

Maximal transcriptional activity of STAT3 requires both phosphorylation on tyrosine 705 and serine 727 [27]. In consideration of the inhibitory effect of compound 7a on p-STAT3 in tumor cells, we performed electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) to evaluate the inhibition of STAT3:STAT3 DNA-binding activity. After treated with compound 7a (1–4 μM) or Stattic (4 μM) for 24 h, nuclear extracts of MDA-MB-231 cells were incubated with hSIE probe and EMSA assay was performed. The capability of STAT3:STAT3 binding DNA was decreased by compound 7a at a start concentration at 1 μM and an obvious diminish at 4 μM as compared with Stattic at 4 μM (Fig. 7B), which indicated that compound 7a effectively suppressed STAT3 activation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 7a did not affect STAT1 phosphorylation and typical upstream or other kinases of STAT3
ce:section.ce:para: STAT1, another member of the STATs family, can inhibit cancer cell proliferation and induce apoptosis. As shown in Fig. 7A and Fig. S1B by western blotting assays, compound 7a and Stattic had little effect on STAT1 phosphorylation. Upstream kinases (such as JAK2, Src) can phosphorylate tyrosine residues of STAT3 and the Erk family of mitogen-activated protein kinases can stimulates STAT3 phosphorylation on Ser727 [54]. We evaluated the effects of compound 7a on the phosphorylation of JAK2, Src and Erk1/2 b y western blotting assays to investigate the selectivity of compound 7a targeting the phosphorylation of STAT3. As shown in Fig. 7C, compound 7a had no effect on p-JAK2, p-Src and p-Erk1/2 as same as Stattic (Fig. S1C). These results showed that the phosphorylation inhibition of STAT3 by compound 7a was selective and independent of these related kinases.

Given that compound 7a could inhibit the phosphorylation of STAT3 without influencing other related kinases, to determine whether compound 7a is a direct STAT3 SH2 domain inhibitor, we performed docking assay for predicting potential binding modes of compound 7a with STAT3 SH2 domain (PDB: 1BG1). As shown in Fig. 8 , the benzo [b]thiophene 1, 1-dioxide and coumarin fragments of compound 7a perfectly overlapped with the native hot spot pTyr705 site and side pocket of STAT3 SH2 domain via forming four hydrogen bonding interactions with the Arg 609 residues (distance = 1.593 Å and 2.144 Å), Lys 591 residues (distance = 2.146 Å) and Arg 595 residues (distance = 2.185 Å). The predicted binding energy was −7.8 kcal/mol. Moreover, suitable length and angle of piperazine fragment contributed to interact with the two binding pocket of STAT3. Therefore, compound 7a was speculated to be a direct STAT3 SH2 domain inhibitor.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 7a affected the expression of STAT3 targeted genes
ce:section.ce:para: Several proteins such as anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 protein and Cyclin D1 involved in cell cycle progression have been found to associate directly with STAT3. Hence, looking for more insights in the mechanism of compound 7a on the STAT3 pathway, we estimated the effects of compound 7a on the expression levels of Bcl-2 and Cyclin D1 using western blotting and compared with Stattic (Fig. S1A). After treatment with compound 7a for 24 h, Bcl-2 and Cyclin D1 protein levels were decreased in a concentration-dependent manner (Fig. 7D). These results demonstrated that compound 7a suppressed the protein levels of p-STAT3 (Y705) and p-STAT3 (S727), inhibited STAT3:STAT3 DNA-binding activity and consequently down-regulated the expression of STAT3 target genes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Compound 7a exhibited antitumor activity in vivo
ce:section.ce:para: To evaluate in vivo antitumor effect of compound 7a, we established a mouse-xenograft model bearing inoculation of STAT3 over-expressed and over-activated mouse breast cancer 4T1 cells as reported previously [34,50,55]. The mice were randomly assigned and treated with doses (10 mg/kg, 20 mg/kg) of compound 7a or the vehicle daily by intraperitoneal injection for 14 consecutive days. As shown in Fig. 9 , compound 7a significantly inhibited tumor volume (52.29% decrease at 10 mg/kg, 61.20% decrease at 20 mg/kg) and weight (39.67% decrease at 10 mg/kg, 56.86% decrease at 20 mg/kg). Western blotting assays showed that compound 7a inhibited the p-STAT3 (Y705) level in tumor tissue. All these results indicated that compound 7a possessed potent antitumor activity against implanted 4T1 breast tumors growth.

In the present study, we have designed and synthesized a series of mitochondria-targeting STAT3 inhibitors by conjugating BTP moiety with N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin fluorophore, and evaluated their anticancer activities in vitro and in vivo. In contrast to the compound BTP, new STAT3 inhibitors revealed remarkable higher potency, represented by the most potent compound 7a. Compound 7a showed more anticancer activity and comparatively better safety than the positive STAT3 inhibitor Stattic. Subcellular localization studies visualized that compound 7a was accumulated to mitochondria by the aid of the fluorescent N, N-diethyl-7-aminocoumarin moiety. The promoted ROS and reduced Δψ m by compound 7a induced mitochondrial apoptosis pathway and the cessation of tumor cells colony formation. Further biological evaluation showed that compound 7a inhibited Tyr705 and Ser727 STAT3 phosphorylation, STAT3:STAT3 DNA-binding activity and regulated the expression of the STAT3 downstream genes Bcl-2 and Cyclin D1, with little effect on the phosphorylation of STAT1 and related kinases (JAK2, Src and Erk1/2). Docking studies revealed that compound 7a might be a STAT3-SH2 domain inhibitor. Furthermore, compound 7a significantly inhibited breast cancer 4T1 implanted tumor growth in vivo. In summary, all evidences highlight that compound 7a is a promising mitochondria-targeting STAT3 inhibitor for cancer therapy.

All chemicals were obtained from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Reaction progress was monitored using analytical thin layer chromatography (TLC) on precoated silica gel GF254 plates (Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Plant, Qingdao, China) and the spots were detected under UV light (254 nm). Melting point was measured on an XT-4 point instrument and uncorrected. IR (KBr-disc) spectra were recorded by Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker ACF-500 spectrometer at 25 °C and referenced to TMS. Chemical shifts are reported in ppm (δ) using the residual solvent line as internal standard. Splitting patterns were designed as s, singlet; br. s, broad single; d, doublet; t, triplet; m, multiplet. The purity of all compounds used for biological evaluation was confirmed to be higher than 95% through analytical HPLC performed with Agilent 1100 HPLC System. Mass spectra were obtained on a MS Agilent 1100 Series LC/MSD Trap mass spectrometer (ESI-MS) and a Mariner ESI-TOF spectrometer (HRESI-MS), respectively.

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedures for the preparation of 2a-2n
ce:section.ce:para: To a stirred solution of compound 1a-1n (9.90 mmol) in DMF (20 mL) were added methyl thioglycolate (10.9 mmol) and potassium carbonate (39.6 mmol). The resulting mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 15 h. The DMF was removed under reduced pressure, water (50 mL) was added and the mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (2 × 40 mL). The combined organic layers were dried with sodium sulfate, filtered, and the solvents were removed under reduced pressure to afford the title compound 2a-2n [31,34] .
Yield 76%, pale yellow solid; m. p. 87–88 °C; 1H NMR (600 MHz, DMSO‑d 6) δ 9.00 (s, 1H), 8.44 (s, 1H), 8.37 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 1H), 8.32 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 3.92 (s, 3H).

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedures for the preparation of 3a-3n
ce:section.ce:para: The solution of compound 2a-2n (1.1 mmol) in water (10 mL) was stirred and then potassium hydroxide pellets (5.4 mmol) were added, which was refluxed for 3 h. The aqueous layer was then acidified to pH 1 with 1 M hydrochloric acid solution. The aqueous layer was extracted with dichloromethane (3 × 15 mL). The combined organic layers were dried with sodium sulfate, filtered, and the solvents were removed under reduced pressure to afford the title compound 3a-3n [31,34].

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedures for the preparation of 4a-4o
ce:section.ce:para: To a solution of 3a-3o (1.94 mmol) in anhydrous dichloromethane (20.0 mL) and HATU (2.33 mmol) in the presence of DIEA (3.89 mmol), tert-butylpiperazine-1-carboxylate (2.14 mmol) was added and stirred for 12 h. After completion, dilute hydrochloric acid solution was added, extracted with dichloromethane and washed with saturated sodium carbonate solution three times. The combined organic layers were washed with brine and dried with sodium sulfate, filtered, concentrated, and purified by silica gel chromatography with petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as eluent to give pure 4a-4o [34] .

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedures for the preparation of 5a-5o and 8
ce:section.ce:para: 3-Chloroperbenzoic acid (2.5 mmol) was added to the stirred solution of compound 4a-4o and benzo [b]thiophene (1.0 mmol) in dichloromethane (20 mL) in portions over a 20–30 min period. The mixture was heated to reflux for about 5 h and monitored by TLC. After completion, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and sodium hydrogen sulfite (20 mL) was added. The solution was stirred for 15 min and extracted with dichloromethane. The organic phase was washed with aqueous sodium bicarbonate (2 × 10 mL). The organic phase was separated, washed with brine and dried with sodium sulfate, filtered, and the solvents were removed under reduced pressure to give the sulfone compound 5a-5o and 8 [31,34].

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedures for the preparation of 6
ce:section.ce:para: 4-(Diethylamino)-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (25.87 mmol) and diethyl malonate (5.89 mL, 38.81 mmol) were dissolved in anhydrous enthanol (50 mL), and then piperidine (5.17 mmol, 512 μL) was added. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 12 h, and then the solvents were removed under reduced pressure, water (50 mL) was added and the mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (2 × 40 mL). The combined organic layers were dried with sodium sulfate, filtered, and the solvents were removed under reduced pressure to afford the ethyl ester.

The ethyl ester was dissolved in 2 M sodium hydroxide solution (40 mL) and was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The solution was acidified with 2 M hydrochloric acid solution, then the precipitate was collected and washed with water to afford compound 6 [56].

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedures for the preparation of 7a-7o
ce:section.ce:para: To a solution of 5a-5o (1.0 mmol) in DCM (4 mL) was added TFA (1 mL) at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h and then the solvents were removed under reduced pressure. The crude mixture was used as such (without further purification) in the following step. The crude N-Boc deprotected compound (2.11 mmol) was dissolved in anhydrous dichloromethane (10 mL) and HATU (2.29 mmol) in the presence of DIEA (7.65 mmol), compound 6 (1.91 mmol) was added and stirred for 12 h. After completion, dilute hydrochloric acid solution was added and extracted with dichloromethane, washed with saturated sodium carbonate solution three times. The combined organic layers were washed with brine and dried with sodium sulfate, filtered, concentrated, and purified by silica gel chromatography with petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as eluent to give pure 7a-7o.

All cell lines were purchased from Cell Bank of Shanghai Institute of Biochemistry and Cell Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (Shanghai, China). Cancer cell line human breast carcinoma MDA-MB-231, human hepatocellular carcinoma HepG2 cells, human colonic carcinoma HCT-116 cells and human colonic epithelial L02 cells were cultured in Dulbecco modified Eagle medium (DMEM) plus 10% (v/v) fetal bovine serum (FBS), 50 μg/mL penicillin and 50 μg/mL streptomycin. Human breast carcinoma MCF-7 cells, human normal breast MCF-10 A cells and mouse breast carcinoma 4T1 cells were cultured in RPMI 1640 medium, supplemented with 10% (v/v) FBS. All cell lines were incubated at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere containing 5% CO2.

Cell viability was measured via MTT assay. Cells (MDA-MB-231, HepG2, HCT-116, MCF-7, MCF-10 A, L02) were seeded in 96-well culture plates at a density of 3000–6000 cells per well. After overnight incubation, the cells were treated with different concentrations of test compounds for 48 h at 37 °C. The percentage of DMSO in the medium not exceeded 0.1% MTT (5 mg/mL) was dissolved in PBS and filter-sterilized, then 20 μL of the prepared MTT solution was added to each well and the cells were incubated for another 3.5 h until a purple precipitate was visible. The formed formazan crystals were dissolved in DMSO (150 μL/well) by continuous shaking for 10 min. The absorbance was read by an ELISA reader (SpectraMax Plus 384, Molecular Devices, Sunnyvale, CA) at a test wavelength of 570 nm and a reference wavelength of 630 nm. The cytotoxic activity was expressed as the IC50 values. All experiments were conducted in triplicate and repeated more than three times.

The anti-proliferative activity of the compound 7a was measured using colony forming assays. MDA-MB-231 cells were plated in 6-well culture plates (1000 cells per well), and treated by compound 7a at different concentrations for 24 h. Then culture medium containing was discarded, and cells were subcultured to fresh medium. Cells were allowed to grow for 10–14 days until the colonies were visible. The cells in plates were then stained with crystal violet solution (Sigma Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) and the results of colonies were taken photos manually.

Apoptosis was determined by flow cytometry in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. An Annexin V-FITC/PI double-staining assay was used to analyze the apoptosis, for which 3.0 × 105 MDA-MB-231 cells were incubated with various concentrations of compound 7a for 24 h. Then the cells were harvested, washed and stained with 5 μL Annexin V-FITC and 10 μL propidium iodide at room temperature in the dark for 15 min. Cells were then analyzed by flow cytometry (488 nm excitation and 525 nm emission filters) using BD Accuri C6 flow cytometer (Becton & Dickinson Company, Franklin Lakes, NJ).

MDA-MB-231 cells and MCF-7 cells were seeded into 96-well plate and cultured in medium supplemented with 10% FBS in an atmosphere of 5% CO2 at 37 °C. After 24 h, 100 μL of fresh media containing compound 7a was added and incubated for 60 min. After treatment, the medium was removed, and the cells were washed with PBS for three times. Cells were then incubated with 1 μM MitoTracker Red or 1 μM LysoTracker Red for another 30 min after being fixed in 4% of paraformaldehyde for 10 min. The images of cells were taken under an Image Xpress Micro Confocal analysis.

Protein levels were determined by standard western blotting. MDA-MB-231 cells were incubated with various concentrations of compound 7a (1–4 μM) or Stattic (4 μM) for 24 h. Harvesting after trypsinisation, cells were treated with 1 × RIPA lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 0.25% deoxycholic acid, 1% NP-40, 1 mM EDTA and protease inhibitors PMSF) (Amresco, Solon, USA) to extract the total proteins. An aliquot of proteins from the total cell lysates (40–80 μg per lane) was separated by sodium dodecyl sulfate (10%) polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE, BioRad Laboratories, Hercules, CA), wet-transferred to PDVF membrane (BioRad Laboratories, Hercules, CA) and blotted with primary antibodies specific for Cleaved Caspase-9, Caspase-9, Cleaved Caspase-3, Caspase-3, PARP, Cleaved PARP, STAT3, p-STAT3 (Y705), p-STAT3 (S727), STAT1, p-STAT1 (Y701), p-JAK2, Src, p-Src, p-Erk1/2, Bcl-2, Cyclin D1 and GAPDH, probed with secondary isotype specific antibodies tagged with horseradish peroxidase (Cell Signaling Technology). Bound immunocomplexes were detected using ChemiDOC™ XRS + system (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) of DNA-binding activity
ce:section.ce:para: MDA-MB-231 cells were incubated overnight and then treated with compound 7a (1–4 μM) or Stattic (4 μM) in fresh medium for 24 h and the cells were harvested. Nuclear extract preparations of MDA-MB-231 cells and EMSA analysis were carried out using LightShift® Chemiluminescent EMSA Kit (Thermo Scientific, Inc.) following the manufacturer's recommended protocol. The 32P labeled oligonucleotide hSIE probe was used to bind STAT3.

Mitochondrial membrane potential was determined using the mitochondrial membrane potential assay kit with JC-1 (Beyotime, Nanjing, China) following the manufacturer's recommended protocol. MDA-MB-231 cells were plated in 6-well culture plates (3 × 105 cells per well), and treated with different concentrations of compound 7a for 24 h. Cells were harvested at 2000 rpm for 5 min and then washed twice with ice-cold PBS, followed by resuspension in JC-1 (5 mg/mL) and incubation at 37 °C for 20 min. After the cells were rinsed three times and suspended in the JC-1 buffer, the JC-1 fluorescence was observed by flow cytometry.

The levels of intracellular ROS were measured by using the oxidation-sensitive dye 5, 6-carboxy-2ʹ, 7ʹ-dichlorofluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA). MDA-MB-231 cells were seeded in 6-well plates at a density of 3 × 105 cells/well and treated with various concentrations of compound 7a for 24 h. After washed three times with serum-free medium and incubated with 10 μM DCFH-DA for 30 min at 37 °C in the dark, cells were washed again, harvested and resuspended in serum-free medium. The samples were then detected by flow cytometry using BD Accuri C6 flow cytometer.

Molecular docking studies were performed to dock our designed small molecules to predict their binding modes and approximate binding free energies to the STAT3 SH2 dimerization sites with computational docking program AutoDock4.2. Compounds 7a were docked using the Lamarckian Genetic Algorithm. The Schrodinger software was used to prepare the macromolecule and ligand. Gasteiger charges were assigned to the ligands by AutoDock Tools. AutoGrid maps were further precomputed for all atom types in the ligand set. After completing 10 million energy evaluations, the root-meansquare deviation threshold was set as 1.5 Å and all the conformations of the ligands in the binding pocket of the macromolecule were clustered. The lowest energy clusters were identified and binding energies were evaluated.

Adult female BALB/c mice (6 weeks of age), of Specified-Pathogens Free (SPF) grade, were purchased from Beijing Vital River Laboratory Animal Technology Co., Ltd. Mice were injected in the right flank area with 4 × 106 breast cancer 4T1 cells in 200 μL of PBS and then randomly divided into three groups (6–8 mice per group) after tumors with a diameter of 3 mm were established. The tumor-bearing mice were intraperitoneally administered with compound 7a (10 or 20 mg/kg) or vehicle for 14 consecutive days. The tumor size was measured by caliper every 2 days to document tumor growth and calculated by the formula: V = 0.52 × a 2 × b (a is the smallest superficial diameter and b is the largest superficial diameter). Drugs were prepared in a hydroxypropyl-beta-cyclodextrin and DMSO mixture (30% hydroxypropyl-beta-cyclodextrin, 10% DMSO and 60% saline) to give a 1 mg/mL or 2 mg/mL solution. After 15 days of treatment, all mice were killed and tumors were segregated, weighed, and stored at −80 °C for later use. Tumor inhibitory ratio TI (%) was calculated as TI (%) = (1 - WT/WV) × 100, where WT and WV were the average tumor weights of the treated and vehicle group respectively.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: This research work was supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No.81673298 and No. 81402791), Natural Science Foundation of the Jiangsu Higher Education Institutions of China for Excellent Young Talents (Grant No. BK20180077), Program for Changjiang Scholars and Innovative Research Team in University (IRT_15R63), Postgraduate Research & Practice Innovation Program of Jiangsu Province (KYCX17_0731).

ce:section.ce:label: Appendix A
ce:section.ce:para: The following is/are the supplementary data to this article:

ce:section.ce:label: Appendix A
ce:section.ce:para: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ejmech.2019.04.024.
